Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading his message: “Can’t wait for our evening together before you leave.” My heart fluttered, knowing how much we both needed this time. It was our only free night before my week-long trip, and he’d planned everything—dinner, a walk, just us. But then, my mother called. “We must leave early tomorrow for the festival. It’s important you’re there for the rituals.” The festival was sacred, a time for prayers and offerings, and my family expected me to be present, fully engaged, not distracted or absent. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on me. As a girlfriend, I wanted to cherish every moment with him, to show him he mattered. As a Hindu, I knew my presence at the festival was not just tradition, but devotion. My mind raced, torn between love and faith, between the warmth of his hand and the sacred flame of the temple. I sat in silence, the evening slipping away, caught between two promises I couldn’t bear to break.
